name: Stephen's Sausage Roll
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP+ Processor: 1.8 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: DX9 / SM2-compatible card ( generally everything made since 2004 should work ) DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: This is the only game that has made me cry at mechanics alone. Twice.  Stephen's Sausage Roll is, quite simply, the greatest puzzle game ever made. It may well be perfect.

A truly brilliant puzzle game. It takes the mechanics so much further than you would imagine, to the point there are genuinely 'Oh my god, did that just happen?' moments. I got 30 hours of thoroughly enjoyable play out of this and can see myself playing it again at some point, so it was worth every penny. I have only positive points to make:  - Very challenging puzzles right from the get-go. - There *is* a learning curve - a very well crafted one - it just starts you off high. I'd say the level of difficulty is consistent throughout (given that you are also learning as you go). - There are a lot of puzzles. - The puzzles are meticulously designed such that they all have very interesting, completely different solutions and you can see how everything was arranged to make that solution and only that solution work. - Pretty much every puzzle twists what you know about the mechanics (some will have you proclaiming 'This is impossible!' before you *get* it). - Every puzzle is super satisfying (to the point I'm shouting YESSSSS after each one). - The graphics and audio are very well designed to not get in the way but also add a lot of character. - Exploring the overworld is very enjoyable. - You truly feel like you've improved as a puzzle solver by the end of it - there's a very definite evolution in the way you think about the puzzles.  There was almost a point early in the game (maybe 2-3 hours in) where I could have stopped playing, simply because I couldn't see where it was going. If you get past that hurdle, you'll be glad you did.  Perfect for puzzle fans. Couldn't recommend it enough. Also recommend having a friend playing the game as well so you can talk about ideas and spur each other on. If you're not sure, give it a try.

21 hours in and 174 perfectly cooked sausages later this game is still blowing my mind. The puzzles can be tough but nothing you can't handle. The game never punishes you for your mistakes as you are free to undo all your moves at any point. I also like how the game lets you play past the point of failure and discover new level and sausage rolling mechanics through trial and error.  I looked up the solution to one puzzle and I regretted it.
A masterpiece of nightmarish and mindbending puzzle design. Not for the faint of heart, or those who do not like sausages.

First off, this game is *difficult*. But it's a fair difficulty if you have experience with puzzles. If you don't have prior experience but want a difficult puzzle game you can actually complete, you would be better off playing either English Country Tune or Snakebird first. Go ahead and pick up those two titles first, and complete them. Those are easier than this, but still quite difficult for a first-timer.  Now, a review for those of us who are actually experienced in puzzle games (but somehow haven't bought this?).  Stephen's Sausage Roll is a puzzle game that, first and foremost, prides itself on having some of the most ludicrously difficult puzzles, yet having merely a small handful of fairly simple rules. Think Fish Fillets, Hana no Puzzle, and Snakebird. You play as the titular Stephen, who has crashed her ship on the Island of Wisdom and must presumably find her way back home. However, the island is strange; it has sand and grass as you'd expect from an island, but it also has mysterious pink cubes, metal grilles, and ghostly versions of Stephen herself.  Oh, and Stephen for some reason holds a giant fork. Don't ask why, because I don't know. Maybe that's her ship's anchor or something.  At this point, you're probably wondering what the gameplay is like. I understand; the trailer doesn't show anything, you don't want to spoil yourself too much by reading reviews on external sites, but you're not sure if this game really is worth the 23GBP. So I'll say this much:  The pink cubes are sausages, the metal grilles are grills, and you have to grill each sausage by pushing them onto the grills. Take care not to burn them or lose them in the water. It's like Sokoban, but more difficult due to the giant fork that Stephen's swinging around, making it annoying for her to move. But that's where the 'puzzle' part of the game comes from.  It's really not too easy to describe the difficulty of a puzzle, but I'll give it a try; on one level, the obvious path of 'push both sausages together' ends up burning one of them. Many people get stuck here when they try and push one of the sausages out the way and fail. On another level, there is a moat around the two solitary grills in the centre, and you somehow need to get the sausage over the moat and onto the grill. Then there's the tricksy Clover level, where you think you have the solution, but need to avoid getting trapped. On yet another level, you have to somehow juggle around three sausages on a small island, while making sure that none of them push each other off the island.  Many times, when I've shown the game to my friends, they've all played a level for 15 minutes and simply given up, claiming that the level is impossible.  Well, that's just the first island. The second island unlocks once you've completed all the puzzles in the first island and not before, so if you're not a completionist for puzzles, this game is probably not for you.  In the second island, there is a new game mechanic introduced; but unlike many other games, this game mechanic had always existed; it was just unapplicable in the first island (no spoilers as to what the mechanic is), and it's at that point that you really gain an appreciation for just how well-designed this game is, if you hadn't already gleaned it from the previous levels.  Basically, what I'm saying is this; if you're not good at puzzles, then your 23GBP would be better spent on The Witness, The Talos Principle, or a combination of cheaper puzzle games; you would probably just get frustrated at this game and refund it after getting stuck on a bunch of levels in the first world. If you're good at puzzles, this should already be in your library, so go play it now.  Oh, and don't worry about the infamous 'Tower' level. It's really not that large of a jump in difficulty.

I dream about sausages now. I think of sausages and how they roll. I wanted an aerodynamic fork, and if you do, this game might be for you.  Deli-cious sau-sages.  Made from succulent pigs. Don't like rolling sausages for moral reasons? This game might be for you.  The geometry of the common marbled sausage is round. This property allows them to be rolled. Rolling a sausage is like playing the piano - hard to master, but very rewarding. Burning a piano is also frowned upon. Much like sausages.  If you lose a sausage at sea, it is lost. Where do you go, little sausage? No High Arts can save you now, my fortune telling friend.  There was a great review here, once. Now, there is something even greater.

To all the people who say this game is overpriced, I highly, highly disagree. This game is full of a lot of content that takes the seemingly simple mechanics and does a lot of cool things with them. Even though the puzzles are excruciatingly hard, the environment and chill music still helps you keep calm. 9.25/10

Stephen's Sausage Roll is one of the big surprises of the year. Super hard, and with a deceptively simple appearance. But it's no-joke one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. Excellent use of space and gradually learning to understand an environment.   It's an investment to make progress, but I appreciate the way it leaves you to work things out for yourself -- and then feels amazing when you do.
Cooking sausages is pretty fun I guess.

This game recreates the feeling of a Rubik's Cube to me. When I have some downtime I fire it up and am in the game almost instantly, with mellow peaceful music and a whole screen of puzzles, some of which I have been stumped on for hours.  A good way to pass some time listening to the hiss of grilling sausage.
This is the best puzzle game this year (and The Witness came out this year).

If you're reading this, you're probably just in the process of talking yourself into or out of buying it. Let me strongly suggest that you buy it. I agree that it's not priced appeallingly based on the marketing materials, but if this is your sort of game, it's REALLY your sort of game. Just buy it.
Stephen's sausage puzzles made Jonathan's line puzzles feel the way I imagined a sausage puzzle would feel.
A finely crafted yet truly meaty puzzle game that leaves a good taste in the mouth. Serves 1. Not suitable for vegetarians.

Do not be fooled. This game will invade your subconscious.  You will play for hours. You will burn many sausages. You will curse at your computer.  You will swear 'That level is impossible.' You will rage-quit.  You will still be thinking about it days later.  You will start the game again, and attempt a level again.  You will finally solve it. You will yell in triumph, and smile.  Then you'll start the process again on the next level.  It's absolutely brilliant. And silly. And frustrating. And weird.  It is an amazing and fun puzzle game that you'll not stop thinking about.   It's will also make an excellent conversation starter. And possibly conversation ender as well, with people walking away with strange looks on their face. You'll be branded a weirdo, as you profess your love of rolling sausages around on the ground.  But you won't mind. Because you'll know the truth. The true beauty that is Stephen's Sausage Roll. And you'll walk away from them, smiling to yourself, eager to get back to the game to solve that one nefarious puzzle that you've been thinking about all week.   Stephen's Sausage Roll.
I finally beat it. Incredible. Wonderful.

'This game is hard.' 'Huh, so maybe it's like SpaceChem. How hard can a puzzle game be?'  (after taking almost half an hour to solve the first puzzle) 'I think I missed the tutorial level. Where is it?'  (after solving the Great Tower) 'Oh...'  I see a negative review saying 'the game is so relentless in its difficulty'. I completely agree with the review. I even understand that the reviewer, who is surely better at this game than I am (I feel even the puzzles before the Great Tower are merciless), does not recommend this game because it's too hard. Yet I should recommend this game. I enjoyed being hopeless while I have been playing this game.  The learning curve can be compared to climbing the height of Mount Everest in a day. Deadly. Do not expect a single puzzle that simply 'displays' the game's mechanism.  My friend recommends Snakebird. I think I should play that too.  Edit: I've been playing Snakebird for some time. Similar to this game, Snakebird has simple idea with advanced yet straightforward mechanics. But so far this game is much more challenging.  Edit 2: After solving all non-cloud puzzles I can definitely say that while Snakebird is a well-made, challenging puzzle game, this game tops that.
